text: The adversary performs suspicious activity on the host consistent with known intrusion behaviors. Intelligence indicates this is consistent with data staging and exfiltration.
The actor attempts to access or reuse credentials from the host to move laterally and maintain access. This activity follows initial access and may support lateral movement.
The intruder searches for files of interest to collect sensitive information for exfiltration. Intelligence indicates this is consistent with data staging and exfiltration.
The adversary downloads a malicious payload from a remote server, likely as part of the initial access or execution phase. This activity may lead to execution of the payload on the host.
The intruder searches for files of interest to collect sensitive information for exfiltration. Observed as part of a persistence and persistence-maintenance phase.
When executed, the loader first creates a directory structure within %APPDATA% using the following command:
Once the ZIP archive has been retrieved, it is then unzipped into the directory that was previously created using the PowerShell "Expand-Archive" cmdlet.
Finally, the loader invokes the newly downloaded Python executable and passes the final payload as a command line argument, executing the next stage of the infection process.
Fortunately for victims, in the samples analyzed the loader incorrectly attempts to invoke the batch file as shown below.
command: C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c cd %appdata%\Microsoft\Network && powershell -Command start script.bat -Verb RunAs

The actor runs a memory-dumping utility (dumpert) against lsass.exe to capture process memory for later analysis. Dumping LSASS memory is a credential dumping technique used to obtain account hashes or secrets that support privilege escalation and lateral movement; it usually requires SYSTEM or elevated access.

Observed use of ProcDump to create a full memory image of lsass.exe (procdump.exe -ma). This activity is classified as LSASS memory dumping and is commonly used to extract credential material (NTLM hashes/cleartext secrets). Typically requires elevated privileges; treat as high-priority credential dumping activity. Recommended detection: alert on procdump usage with -ma targeting lsass.exe and monitor for subsequent movement of dump artifacts off-host.

Observed disabling of the HardwareEvents Windows event log using wevtutil; this action is indicative of anti-forensic behavior intended to limit logging of hardware-related events that could reveal persistence or device tampering.

Observed use of wevtutil to disable the Internet Explorer event channel (set-log internet explorer /enabled:false). Suppressing this log reduces visibility into browser-related events and may be used to hide subsequent defensive-evasion or persistence activity. Detection: alert on wevtutil set-log changes and review recent process activity for evidence of lateral or follow-on actions.

Observed a download-like command that retrieves a document from a remote path into a local user directory, with output redirection to an admin share. This pattern can indicate tool-driven retrieval of payloads or remote files and may precede execution. Detection guidance: monitor inbound file transfers and anomalous SMB activity to admin shares.

Use of this command indicates credential harvesting and post-compromise credential access, often following initial access or lateral movement.

text: Queries the Windows registry uninstall keys to enumerate installed applications (searching for DisplayName). An adversary may use this to discover installed software, versions, and security products to inform follow-on actions such as targeted exploitation, evasion, or payload selection. This activity falls under software/system discovery and registry query during the Discovery phase of an intrusion.

Queries the 32-bit uninstall registry keys (Wow6432Node) to enumerate installed 32-bit applications and their DisplayName. An adversary may use this to identify installed software, versions, and security/AV products to inform targeted exploitation, tooling selection, or evasive measures. This activity is part of software/system discovery and registry enumeration during the Discovery phase.

Queries the current user's uninstall registry keys to enumerate per-user installed applications (searching for DisplayName). An adversary may use this to identify user-installed software, versions, and potential security products to inform targeted exploitation, tooling selection, or evasive measures. This activity is part of software/system discovery and registry enumeration during the Discovery phase.

Downloads and executes a PowerShell script from a remote HTTP server using `IEX (New-Object Net.Webclient).DownloadString(...)`, then runs `Get-NetSubnet` to enumerate network subnets. An adversary may use this to stage tools or payloads (ingress tool transfer), execute remote code, and map network topology for lateral movement, targeting, or further discovery. This activity is commonly observed during staging and Discovery phases.

Downloads and executes a PowerShell script from a remote HTTP server using IEX, then runs `Get-NetComputer -ping` (PowerView) to enumerate reachable hosts via ICMP. An adversary may use this to stage additional tooling or payloads (ingress tool transfer/remote code execution) and perform internal host discovery/network scanning to build a list of live targets for lateral movement or further reconnaissance.

Downloads and executes a PowerShell script from a remote HTTP server, then runs `Get-NetComputer -ping -operatingsystem *server*` to enumerate reachable systems with server-class operating systems. An adversary may use this to stage tooling (ingress/remote code execution) and perform targeted network/Active Directory discovery to identify server hosts for lateral movement, privilege escalation, or further exploitation.
